case_name: M/s. Mohanlal Hargovindas v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 221 of 1964 from judgment and order dated September 5, 1963 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 334 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 221 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 5, 1963 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 334 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant is the Manager of a Bidi company manufacturing and labelling factory of M/s. Mohanlal Hargovindas, Jabalpur, engaged in purchase and sale of Bidi in Madhya Pradesh and other states.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the Manager of a Bidi companynting and labelling factory of M s. Mohanlal Har- govindas, Jabalpur, who are engaged in the trade of purchase and sale of Bidi in the State of Madhya Pradesh and other States of India.

facts.text: In 1951, State of Madhya Pradesh fixed rates of minimum wages for workmen in Bidi making manufactories under Minimum Wages Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: In 1951 the State of Madhya Pradesh fixed rates of minimum wages payable to workmen engaged in Bidi making manufactories. This was done in accordance with the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948  Central Act 11 of 1948 .

facts.text: Minimum wages rates revised in 1956 by notification dated 23rd February 1956.

anchor.surface_text: These rates of minimum wages were revised in the year 1956 by a numberification of the Madhya Pradesh Government dated the 23rd February 1956.

facts.text: New minimum wages rates notified by MP Government on 30th December 1958, effective from January 1, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: New rates of minimum wages for workmen engaged in the Bidi making manufactories were numberified by the Madhya Pradesh Government by a numberification dated the 30th December 1958. The numberification directed that these rates would companye into force from January 1, 1959.

facts.text: Validity of 1958 notification successfully challenged by appellant before Madhya Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of this numberification was however successfully challenged by the present appellant before the Madhya Pradesh High Court.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Legislature enacted Minimum Wages (Madhya Pradesh Amendment and Validation) Act, 1961 (Act No. 23 of 1961) introducing Section 31A into Central Act 11 of 1948 to validate 1958 notification.

anchor.surface_text: To meet the situation the Madhya Pradesh Legislature enacted the Minimum Wages  Madhya Pradesh Amendment and Validation  Act, 1961- Madhya Pradesh Act No. 23 of 1961 . Section 31A which was introduced by this Act into the Central Act  No. 11 of 1948  provided that the rates of minimum wages fixed or revised under the numberification of the 30th December 1958 shall be and shall always be deemed to have been validly fixed and revised...

facts.text: Appellant and other bidi manufacturers challenged validity of 1961 Act before MP High Court under Art. 226; High Court struck down s.31A on 2nd May 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and some other Bidi manufactories of Madhya Pradesh challenged the validity of this Act before the High Court by petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The High Court allowed the applications, struck down s. 31A as invalid... The High Court gave its decision on the 2nd May 1962.

facts.text: On 21st June 1962, Madhya Pradesh Ordinance No. 4 of 1962 passed fixing minimum wages rates retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st June 1962 the Madhya Pradesh Ordinance No. 4 of 1962 was passed fixing rates of minimum wages retrospec- tively.

facts.text: Ordinance replaced by Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 (Act No. 16 of 1962).

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance was later replaced by an Act, the Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962.

facts.text: On 5th October 1962, appellant filed application under Art. 226 and 227 challenging validity of Act 16/1962.

anchor.surface_text: On the 5th October 1962, the appellant made an application to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh under Art. 226 and Art. 227 of the Constitution challenging the validity of this Act...

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court held Act 16/1962 valid and disallowed appellant's application on September 5, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 5, 1963 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 334 of 1962.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on April 21, 1964 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: Sen and I. N. Shroff, for the respondents. April 21, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-

facts.text: Challenge to Act 16/1962 based on three grounds: not independent legislation but validation of 1958 notification; unreasonable restriction on Art.19(1)(f)(g); contravenes Art.20(1).

anchor.surface_text: The challenge to the validity of the Act is based on three principal grounds. The first is that in enacting Act No. 16 of 1962 the Madhya Pradesh Legislature was really number exer- cising its independent legislative power but only validating the numberification dated the 30th December 1958...

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh legislature had legislative competence under Entry 24 of List III, Seventh Schedule; not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the Madhya Pradesh legislature had the legislative companypetence to make a law as regards minimum wages under Entry 24 of List III  Sch. Seventh .

facts.text: Rates in Table of Act 16/1962 identical to rates in 1958 notification.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that the rates mentioned in the Table are identical with the rates men- tioned in the numberification dated the 30th December, 1958.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Act 16/1962 is valid independent legislation.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention that this Act was number independent legislation cannot therefore be accepted.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Act 16/1962 does not impose unreasonable restrictions on Art.19(1)(f)(g).

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible to accept the argument that the Act is an unreasonable restriction on the appellants fundamental rights under Art. 19 1  f  and  g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Minimum rates under s.3 of Act 16/1962 effective from 1st January 1959, but payable from 21st June 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act makes the new rater, of wages effective from January 1 , 1959... the new rates became payable only on the 21st June 1962

facts.text: Supreme Court held Act 16/1962 does not contravene Art.20(1).

anchor.surface_text: The attack on the validity of the sections on the ground of Art. 20 l  of the Constitution therefore fails.

facts.text: All points raised in appeal fail.

anchor.surface_text: All the points raised in the appeal fail.

facts.text: Proviso to s.4 of Act 16/1962: period of one year in s.20(2) Minimum Wages Act counted from 21st June 1962 for claims prior to Ordinance publication.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that with respect to claims arising out of payment of minimum rates of wages specified in section 3 pertaining to a period prior to the publication of the Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Ordinance, 1962  4 of 1962  in the Gazette, the period of one year...
This appeal raises the question of the validity of the Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962  Act No. 16 of 1962 .

concepts.interpretation: Court holds the Act is valid independent legislation fixing minimum wages retrospectively from 1 Jan 1959 but payable from 21 Jun 1962, not violating Arts. 19 or 20.

issues.text: What is the validity of the Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 (Act No. 16 of 1962)?

anchor.surface_text: This appeal raises the question of the validity of the Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962  Act No. 16 of 1962 .

issues.text: Whether in enacting Act No. 16 of 1962 the Madhya Pradesh Legislature exercised its independent legislative power or merely validated the notification dated 30th December 1958?

anchor.surface_text: The first is that in enacting Act No. 16 of 1962 the Madhya Pradesh Legislature was really number exer- cising its independent legislative power but only validating the numberification dated the 30th December 1958

issues.text: Whether by giving retrospective effect to the rates of wages fixed by the Act, the State imposed unreasonable restrictions on fundamental rights under Art. 19(1)(f) and (g)?

anchor.surface_text: The second ground is that by giving retrospective effect to the rates of wages fixed by this Act the State has put unreasonable restrictions on the appellants fundamental rights under Art. 19 l  f   g  of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether by making provisions of ss. 20 and 22 of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948 applicable to wages fixed by the Act, it contravened Art. 20(1)?

anchor.surface_text: The last ground on which the Act was challenged as invalid is thatby making provisions of s. 20 and s. 22 of the Central Act No. 11 of 1948 applicable to the wages number fixed the Act has companytravened Art. 20 1  of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the minimum rates of wages fixed by s. 3 became payable from 1st January 1959 or from 21st June 1962?

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act makes the new rater, of wages effective from January 1 , 1959. Section 4 makes the various provisions of the Central Act No. 11 of 1948 available for revision and enforcement of the rates as specified in s. 3.

arguments.claim: In enacting Act No. 16 of 1962 the Madhya Pradesh Legislature was really not exercising its independent legislative power but only validating the notification dated the 30th December 1958 which it was not competent to do.

anchor.surface_text: The first is that in enacting Act No. 16 of 1962 the Madhya Pradesh Legislature was really not exercising its independent legislative power but only validating the notification dated the 30th December 1958 which it was not competent to do.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the rates mentioned in the Table are identical with the rates men- tioned in the numberification dated the 30th December, 1958. The effect of enactme

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislature had competence under Entry 24 List III; s2 definitions common device; s3 fixes rates anew even if identical to 1958; independent even if effect same as validation.

arguments.claim: Language of s.2 shows dependent and not independent legislation as expressions defined with reference to Minimum Wages Act 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad laid stress on the language of s. That section merely says that the expressions used in this Act shalt have the same meaning for the purpose of this Act as defined in the Minimum Wages Act of 1948.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: m rates of wages in certain scheduled employments. That is stated in the preamble and is plain from s. 3 itself. The fact ,that rates mentioned in the

arguments.court_reasoning: Definition of expressions with reference to other Act is well known legislative device for brevity; effective even if other Act ceases.

arguments.claim: Object of s.3 was to validate minimum rates as fixed by 1958 notification and nothing more.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad next urged that quite clearly the object of s. 3 was to validate the minimum rates of wages as fixed by the notification dated the 30th December 1958 and nothing more.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ection 3 of the Act makes the new rater, of wages effective from January 1 , 1959. Section 4 makes the various provisions of the Central Act No. 11 of

arguments.court_reasoning: s.3 fixes wages at rates in Table for certain employments; rates identical but legislature fixing for itself; stated in preamble and plain from s.3.

arguments.claim: By giving retrospective effect to rates of wages fixed by Act the State has put unreasonable restrictions on fundamental rights under Art. 19(1)(f) and (g).

anchor.surface_text: The second ground is that by giving retrospective effect to the rates of wages fixed by this Act the State has put unreasonable restrictions on the appellants fundamental rights under Art. 19(1)(f) & (g) of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . 11 of 1961 was issued on August 1, 1961. By this Ordinance the material provisions of the earlier Act of 1950 were validated and brought into force

arguments.court_reasoning: Restriction exists but not unreasonable; retrospectivity relevant but not decisive per precedents; employers had notice and should have provisioned; payable only from 21 Jun 1962 per s.4 proviso.

arguments.claim: Retrospective operation for past period imposes unreasonable restriction due to financial difficulties: arrears considerable, accounts closed, profits distributed, surplus spent or invested.

anchor.surface_text: How is it possible for the employer, it is urged, to pay such arrears which might amount in many cases to considerable sums of money when the accounts for the past years had been closed, profits had been distributed and the available surplus had either been spent or invested in other ways?

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e provisions for payments on these very rates, even though they intended to challenge the validity of the previous Act and ultimately succeeded in tha

arguments.court_reasoning: Hardship imaginary; employers expected as good businessmen to provision for purported valid law rates despite challenge.

arguments.claim: s.3 makes new rates payable from 1st January 1959 for past period, leading to liability for compensation under s.20(3) and prosecution under s.22 for past omissions.

anchor.surface_text: But, urges the learned counsel, s. 3 of the Act while giving to the rates of wages fixed by the Act retrospective effect from the 1st January 1959 has also made wages at these new rates payable on January 1, 1959 for the past period.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: these words, it is urged on behalf of the appellant, the legislature number only made the minimum wages effective from the 1st January 1959 but also

arguments.court_reasoning: Textual reading of s.3: 'payable... and be enforceable with effect from 1 Jan 1959'; 'be' before enforceable shows no payment date prescribed in s.3; s.4 proviso fixes limitation from 21 Jun 1962 meaning payable then.

arguments.claim: Even after 21 Jun 1962, unreasonable to expect immediate payment: time to acquaint with Act and arrange funds, risk of compensation application under s.20.

anchor.surface_text: It was then urged that it would be unreasonable to expect the employer to be able to make such payment on the 21st June 1962, the date of publication of the Ordinance. Some time would elapse...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 11 of 1948  as a result of the mere passing of the Act is therefore groundless. It is clear that the duty to pay at these rates arose only on and from

arguments.court_reasoning: Theoretical risk but practically non-existent; compensation discretionary, unlikely if paid soon after; prosecution requires prior s.20 application and sanction.

arguments.claim: By making ss.20 and 22 of Central Act 11/1948 applicable to wages fixed, Act contravenes Art.20(1).

anchor.surface_text: The last ground on which the Act was challenged as invalid is that by making provisions of s. 20 and s. 22 of the Central Act No. 11 of 1948 applicable to the wages fixed the Act has contravened Art. 20(1) of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ct the employer to be able to make such payment on the 21st June 1962, the date of publication of the Ordinance. Some time would elapse, it is pointed

arguments.court_reasoning: No violation as rates payable only from 21 Jun 1962 not 1 Jan 1959; no liability for past acts before law publication.

arguments.claim: Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 is valid.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 5, 1963 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 334 of 1962.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ver that on a proper companystruction of ss. 3 and 4, the new rates of wages for the past period bec

arguments.court_reasoning: All points raised in appeal fail.

arguments.claim: Retrospective operation of legislation is relevant but not decisive test of reasonableness under Art.19(1)(f)(g).

anchor.surface_text: We have no hesitation in agreeing to the proposition that the retrospective operation of legislation is a relevant circumstance in deciding its reasonableness. It is, however, clearly established by a long series of decisions of this Court that this is not necessarily a decisive test.

arguments.claim: In Rai Ramkrishna v. State of Bihar, retrospective validation curing judicial defect after long proceedings not unreasonable even for 10 years.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention in this connection the decision of this Court in Rai Ramkrishna v. State of Bihar. There the Court had to consider the question whether the retrospective operation of the Bihar Taxation... observations apply fully to legislation here.

arguments.claim: s.3 does not prescribe date when new rates become payable; only makes enforceable from 1 Jan 1959.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied however that s. 3 of the impugned Act does not make the new rates of wages payable on the 1st January 1959. The words used are ... as if the provisions herein contained have been in force at all material times.

arguments.claim: s.4 proviso indicates new rates became payable on 21st June 1962.

anchor.surface_text: An examination of s. 4 of the Act further makes it clear beyond any reasonable doubt that it was the intention of the legislature that new rates became payable only on the 21st June 1962... the period of one year ... counted with effect from the 21st June, 1962.

holdings.text: The Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 (Act No. 16 of 1962) is valid independent legislation and not a mere validation of the 1958 notification.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that the rates mentioned in the Table are identical with the rates men- tioned in the numberification dated the 30th December, 1958. The effect of enactment of s. 3 would therefore be the same as if the numberification of 1958 had been validated. To say that,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature competent under Entry 24 List III; s.2 definitions are standard device; s.3 fixes rates anew in Table despite identical to 1958 notification; preamble indicates independent fixation, not disguised validation.

holdings.text: The Act does not impose unreasonable restrictions on fundamental rights under Article 19(1)(f) and (g).

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible to accept the argument that the Act is an unreasonable restriction on the appellants fundamental rights under Art. 19 1  f  and  g  of the Constitution. Restriction there undoubtedly

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrospectivity relevant but not decisive per precedents like Rai Ramkrishna; employers had notice of purported valid rates and should have provisioned; hardship imaginary; rates payable only from 21 June 1962 per s.4 proviso, reducing burden; compensation/prosecution risks theoretical and discretionary.

holdings.text: Section 3 of the Act does not make the new minimum rates of wages payable from 1st January 1959 but makes them enforceable from that date as if always in force.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied however that s. 3 of the impugned Act does number make the new rates of wages payable on the 1st January 1959. The words used are ... as if the provisions herein companytained

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading: 'shall be payable... and be enforceable with effect from 1st January 1959'; 'be' before enforceable shows no payment date in s.3; distinguishes payable from enforceable.

holdings.text: The proviso to Section 4 indicates that the new rates became payable only on 21st June 1962.

anchor.surface_text: An examination of s. 4 of the Act further makes it clear beyond any reasonable doubt that it was the intention of the legislature that new rates became payable only on the 21st June 1962...

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4 applies Central Act provisions including s.20 limitation; proviso explicitly counts 1-year limitation from 21 June 1962 for pre-Ordinance claims, indicating payability date.

holdings.text: The Act does not contravene Article 20(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The attack on the validity of the sections on the ground of Art. 20 l  of the Constitution therefore fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No ex post facto liability as rates payable only from 21 June 1962 publication, not 1 Jan 1959; no offence or conviction for acts before law in force.

holdings.text: The Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 is valid.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal raises the question of the validity of the Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962  Act No. 16 of 1962 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: All three challenge grounds rejected: independent legislation; no unreasonable Art.19 restriction; no Art.20 violation.

holdings.text: Retrospective operation of legislation is a relevant circumstance but not a decisive test for reasonableness under Article 19(1)(f) and (g).

anchor.surface_text: We have numberhesitation in agreeing to the proposition that the retrospective operation of legislation is a relevant circumstance in deciding its reasonableness. It is, however, clearly established

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmed by long series of Supreme Court decisions; applied from Rai Ramkrishna v. State of Bihar where 10-year retrospectivity upheld post-judicial invalidation.

precedents.citation: Rai Ramkrishna v. State of Bihar 1

anchor.surface_text: Rai Ramkrishna v. State of Bihar 1 . There the Court had to companysider the question whether the retrospective operation of the Bihar Taxation of Passengers and Goods Carried by Public Service Motor Vehicles Act, 1961 put such an unreasonable restriction on the fundamental rights guaranteed under Art. 19 1  f  and  g  of the Constitution as to make the Act invalid to the extent of its retrospective operation. The Bihar Finance Act, 1950  Bihar Act XVII of 1950  had imposed a tax on passengers and goods carried by public service motor vehicles in Bihar. In an appeal arising out of a suit filed by the passengers and owners of goods, this Court struck down Part 111. of the -,aid Act as unconstitutional. This judgment was pronounced on the 12th  1  1964 1 S.C.R. 897. December 1960.

precedents.case_name: Rai Ramkrishna v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: retrospective operation of validating legislation covering a long period is not necessarily unreasonable restriction on fundamental rights under Art. 19(1)(f) and (g)
precedents.cited_holding: if after the final judicial verdict is pronounced in the matter the legislature passes a validating Act, it may well cover a long period taken by the judicial proceedings in court and yet it would be inappropriate to hold that because the retrospective operation covers a long period, therefore, the restriction imposed by it is unreasonable

justification_sets.label: Section 3, MP Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 support
Section 3, MP Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 support

anchor.surface_text: The attack on the validity of the sections on the ground of Art. 20 l  of the Constitution therefore fails. All the points raised in the appeal fail.

outcome.relief_summary: All challenges to the validity of the Madhya Pradesh Minimum Wages Fixation Act, 1962 rejected; High Court order upheld
